review_title: Strong foundations with forward looking mgmt
pros:
Singtel will always be like a home to me. Though the region and telco as an industry is getting increasingly competitive, Singtel is one of the most progressive telcos in the world and have been at the forefront of trying to disrupt itself and foster innovation. There is much to learn from the talents and remarkable people driving the organization and I truly enjoyed my time with the Singtel family.

Singtel is a unique company to work for where:
1/ It's scale and profitability allows the company to play globally and employees get to tap on resources beyond Singapore.
2/ Mgmt acknowledges the need to stay ahead and there is a big push internally for innovation and diversification (eg. Now we have digital marketing, cyber security, mobility analytics subsidiaries along with big fintech and esports initiatives). Employees thus need to be comfortable with digitalization of processes and on growing adjacent digital thrusts.
3/ The established brand opens doors to various upsides in potential partnerships, vendor support and customer collaborations. Employees thus get to work with leading tech and top brands.
cons: As with large corporations, it takes time to effect change and transform culture. Singtel is heading in the right direction but inevitably there are some departments that actively resists any form of change. There are thus some pockets of teams that are suboptimal in terms of effectiveness and efficiency.

pros: Good staff benefits such as discounted mobile phone monthly subscriptions and free office phone line (with a not-so-good free handset. I got an Nokia slide phone model). If working at Somerset area, staff canteen offers cheap and a good range of food variety. There is also a gym and free medical coverage. I also had the privilege of very good team mates. Overall atmosphere across departments is that people generally do help and respond to one another.
cons: Salary range is low. Recent HR scheme to adjust payout did not do much to raise the overall average remuneration. As all companies are, your "fate" is largely decided by your immediate Manager. Mine was alright, trusting towards me, however, for what really matters such as pay scheme wise, there is little they can do to help raise this. Promotions are incredibly slow (noted an executive promoting to senior executive having stayed there for 5 years, and in another case, an executive of 6 years was not even offered a promotion). I personally feel that it is not a good place to stay for long at entry level. Considering that promotions are hard to come by, you may see your peers in other industries earning much more substantial amounts very quickly.

review_title: Telesales Executive Processing Coordinator in Singapore Telecommunications Limited
job_title: Telesales Executive Processing Coordinator in Singapore
pros:
It is a challenging job. Even though the workload is a lot, it is a very satisfying job. Within a short period, not only did I learnt a lot of things, the organization also further trained me to fit into the working society. These includes the following:
-	Better understanding of how a Multinational corporation (MNC) works especially in telecommunication industry.
-	Good team player and Multitasking capabilities.
-	Proven to have initiative and the ability to work with minimal supervision.
-	Excellent organizational and motivational skills.
-	Knowledge of processing order in telecommunication industry.
cons:
- Due to the fact that this is a project, hence all the staffs are part timers except for one who is a contract staff. In general, part timer's responsibilities are lesser than a contract staff. Therefore, there is a higher chances of hiring immature teenagers or irresponsible part time staffs. This will in fact increase the workload of the contract staff instead of lessen their workload.

- Training is done over and over again since part timers comes and go frequently.

- The workload is a lot. Working over-time is very common. Even so, I am fine with working over-time so long as the work is done.

review_title: A place where dead wood are rewarded, company supported and progressing by a handful of strong leaders
pros:
Work life balance
Centralized office location 
Cheap canteen food 
Nice chilled people to work with
cons:
Some people who have been in the company for many years and rose up the ranks to middle management do the bare minimum and highly administrative work but still get away, performance unmeasured. When restructuring happens it’s just “passing the turd”, no consequences. 
Some MMs have command and control attitude, unable to flex their leadership style to different people, only care about rubbing shoulders with the higher ups, treating their underlinks as just a number.  Feedback is a joke. Stay obedient and tell them what they want to hear and stay in the dark. You’ll survive 20 years doing that.

review_title: More work needs to be done to retain talents.
pros: Strong local branding, stable environment. There are initiatives for the company to innovate and aspire to be an ICT company, rather than just a traditional telco. (Maybe) good training ground.
cons:
This view may not represent the culture of Singtel as a while, but genuinely the middle management needs training in leadership. There is lack of empathy despite the fact that people are being overworked every day. To some people, it’s impossible to work for someone for 8 - 10 hours a day when their bosses aren’t personally involved and don’t care about anything other than your production yield.  

Communication skill needs to be improved. Certain times there is a communication breakdown and people do not know what is the right expectation.  

Politics is rampant and prevent the real matters from being solved.

pros: Staff discounts for Singtel products
cons: working culture is not supportive

review_title: Stable, good perks and many experienced professionals
pros:
The company is stable and takes care of their employees - remuneration wise and available facilities for the staff to use. This includes having places to have conducive environment for meetings. 

Team leads/directors take time to speak to the team, address everyone in the day to day, work in progress meetings, provide feedback and update on business numbers and direction for both long and short. 

My team also definitely knew how to have fun and celebrate at the right times and at the right moments. Direct bosses were also very empowering, providing opportunity for you to shine.
cons:
Career progression is slow, especially if you want to achieve more in a shorter amount of time. you need to be prepared to spend more time at work and commit to the fast-paced environment to pick up fast.

The company organisation is very big so it can get very complex when managing other stakeholders - something that cannot be avoided with a big company.

pros: Stable company. Good revenue stream from investment from regional telco. Can see the enterprise leaders working hard to beat competitions from oversea and keep the company updated to current competition.
cons:
Many complacency in company because of stability. Leadership should lead and appreciate  managers that get the work done than those who have nice presentation slides, yet can't perform. Outsourcing becomes a norm, more and more into India. Please focus on developing local suppliers quality and supportability so that they can grow together. 

Many global telco or MNC have their own inhouse shared services than outsource to external parties. Outsourcing is easy, however when problem arises to migrate back will be painful. Place of jurisdiction and regulation changes can pose as issues in future too. Should benchmark against the world number top 3 telco in their practices which has already proven.

review_title: Great company - only if you're in the "inner circle"
pros: Awesome company; visionary but with the usual bureaucracy which takes time to navigate around. Great support from all teams and associate telecoms so if you're in any difficulty in any work you can easily reach out for support! Base salary is comparable to other similar local MNCs. Various products, services and policies are made in good decisions for customers and company.
cons: Your performance review is dependent on whether you're in the "inner circle" or not. You can achieve and meet your yearly KPIs and yet still given a poor performance review. The management avoids stating that officially in your performance review document. You might be curious why you're achieving so much, and yet thrown off the bus because you're not within the circle of "friendship"

pros: Stable work environment. Decent remuneration, performance bonuses and increment on a yearly basis.
cons: My job scope was limited and lacked challenge. I got the general feeling that the middle management folks were more focused on their own political agenda then proper business objectives. Thus, the overall work culture lacks the collaborative spirit and growth mentality. Many of the them have risen up the ranks through the years, so they have gotten complacent with their job and lack the perspective of what is happening out of Singtel.

pros:
If u are even remotly good stay away from Digital Unit in IT. management from top to bottom is very bad.   A couple of good middle managers but mostly just managing people, dev manager are no real value. Team member are supportive of each other. 

Pros
Good tech stack lot of interesting applications, u can get good experience
Supportive team members 
Above average pay package and bonus
cons:
New managers are really bad - they don't understand  business or the system complexity and keep pushing their favorite concepts
Your manager won't even know what u are doing on a daily basis . there is no proper dev framework. everone just do their own thing. 
Too much work load all the time in trouble shooting prod issues too many dependency on lot of backend systems and no body have clue what is happening. If prod incident then everybody just rush in. 
You will be criticized by new manager who think they know better when all they want to is  look good, dev practice is a total joke
Almost all team members looking for a job outside and will leave at the first opportunity.

pros: Good colleagues, who are really trying to make something out of their job.
cons:
- horrible politics. Managemnt seemed more intent on looking for someone to blame when things go wrong, then to fix underlying problems. Yelling and screaming is an acceptable way for bosses. Pleasing your bosses and to be blue-eye boy/girl is the gurantee way to get good ratings and bonuses.
- hr policies not well thought through and sucks at explaining to staff. Dont think they really care about employees. Appeared to put a lot of emphasis to win awards.  
- bureacracy. sigh, worst than stat boards.

review_title: Dynamic working environment, but very little support from the top down.
pros: Singtel is a reputable company that certainly helps to build up your resume. It’s a good company to retire to. To ground staff, it pays well to an extent
cons: Top management make extremely uninformed, undesirable business decisions that affect customer experience, and ground staff get the brunt of the customer’s frustrations. In such cases, very little understanding and support offered. Money-minded company. Business best practice values are NOT congruent with the company core values that they preach about.  Hard to align yourself with their best practice values.

review_title: Too much politics and bureaucracy to ever be a true innovator, bell curve performance ranking ruins teamwork
pros:
Stable company - no one ever gets laid off, and contract workers are almost always renewed
Lots of learning opportunities and training courses on offer
Salary is not terrible
cons:
Bureaucracy and paperwork will kill you - more time is spent on form filling and procedural stuff than on real innovation
Politicking is through the roof - everyone lives and dies by the whims of the emperors
Performance evaluation is on a bell curve - everyone has to be ranked, and a fallout of this is that teamwork is not encouraged
Promotion takes years - in most parts of the business, rule of thumb is directors need to be 40+

review_title: Disillusioned. Looking forward to last day here.
pros:
Location 
Industry is used to be associated with stability (no more)
cons:
Demoralising. Toxic. Political. Distrustful. 

Over emphasis on management associates staff who are given preferential treatments at the expense of other staff although they essentially possess much less experience and may not be as loyal and resilient. Previous multiple feedback via voice surveys do not bring changes at all. It just sends a clear message again and again that other staff is not valued and easily replaceable. 

Outsourcing, cost cutting and looming uncertainties bring the worst of management.

Feedback on grievances is either dismissed or met with cold , illogical responses. It is better to keep quiet and pretend nothing happens; at least your image as an obedient staff is kept intact and bosses are happy. 

Not sustainable in the long run. 

Those who can leave have already done so.

review_title: Toxic environment with empire builders, turf guarders and silo-minded feudal lords.
pros: Near orchard road - trust me, you’ll need it as your therapy haven.
cons:
Where do I start? OCD psychotic bosses who will scold you publicly in meetings. Neurotic co-workers who became this way because of their bosses. Many time wasting staff retreats to “build teamwork and bond with each other” but are really wayang sessions. It’s a wonder no one got murdered in these retreats. Inordinate amount of time planning, approving and tracking budgets instead of running after business. Your wives and kids are as good as widows and orphans. You work long hours in the office and then come home to work some more with conference calls. The company will indeed grow, but it will suck the life out of you. 

Ask yourself this simple question - do you want to die young? And live to see your children, and grandchildren? Or do you want to become a wretched and spent barely-alive life form who after having had your life sucked out, see that the company share price is still bloody $3.20. Well, do ya?

pros: Canteen food is cheap and nice. Recreational club has nice facilities (gym, karaoke room, bar). Good location just outside Somerset MRT with many food options. Management is in general receptive and supportive of "change" initiatives.
cons: Huge organization poses challenges. Need to work with and get buy-in from many stakeholders to get anything done. This slows down effort for change. Turnover with lack of documentation process means that most knowledge is somewhat haphazardly gained through verbal questions or sharing. IT support is not strong. Usually the "old birds" who have stayed on for long have outlasted their nicer peers and have mastered the political game, it is your misfortune if you meet such people because you will have a nasty time.

job_title: Senior Cust Care Office in Woodlands New Town,
pros: Health benefits, avg 2mths bonus depending on net profit
cons: High turnover, lack of staffs. Too many redundant department. Focused on customer service, yet when cust rate it’s staff poorly due to company policies, staffs are faulted for not being able to manage. Incentives are based hugely on cust feedback (sms survey). When customer did not rate excellent, due to existing policies or new changes (such as price increase), which will affect a cco’s performance and this resulting loss of KPI incentive. If a cco gets a “good” rating sms, it is not good enough. For example, to get incentive, sms rating received must consists of 70% of excellent. If there is a total of 10 sms survey sent, 7 of them must be rated 5 (excellent). In order to get incentive. (Lowest tier incentive)

review_title: Poor leadership at management level makes poor working culture
pros:
- Got the money to throw at problems (but unfortunately not get the results)
- Got even more money to throw at bad money spent
- Spends time on glassdoor review to put a nice spin to not-so-favourable feedback that “we are listening” (seriously? should spend time fixing culture rather than spinning feedback)
cons:
- High attrition level in the corporate support functions (e.g. HR, Legal, etc.) shows the poor style of leadership at management level. Well-known fact among headhunters that poor working culture (blame and scolding culture) is the main reason given by leavers
- Even had a senior leader commenting that the low Engagement Score (internal rating system) given by the team to the department is negatively affecting this senior leader’s bonus. Oh gosh... had the cheek to say that. Singapore Inc. style - it’s never senior people’s fault

pros:

• Majority of the colleague wants the company to do well.
• Strong team bonding that make challenging situation bearable.
• No room for non-contributor, organisation undergoing drastic digital transformation.
• Top Management occasionally thinks about the well-being of their staff which is rare for a 17,000 staff organisation.
cons:
• Sales driven organisation. Sales figure is no. 1 whereas operation and delivery is place as no. 5,679
• KPI unrealistically challenging, however only a handful met those expectation. Maybe 1 out of 50 folks.
• Process too tedious, loading an order can take up to 9-13 approvals.
• highly regulated by IMDA.
• Regulatory, Audit and Legal call the shots in every aspect in this organisation.
• Product hardly any innovation, follower but not market changer.

cons:

review_title: Lots of products and services to sell, but workload is unbearable!!
pros: Stability is the keyword here. Its akin to an iron ricebowl and there is no risk of getting fired unless you have done something terribly wrong.
cons: Pay is not commensurate with market standards, and basic pay can be much lower than competitors. Too much workload as customers come to you instead of you going to them. There is NO WORK LIFE BALANCE. If you wish to spend 75% of your waking hours doing work and clearing non stop emails, this is the place for you! You are bogged by emails even when going on leave so you can never truly have any rest.

review_title: Worst Company I have ever joined
pros:
I can't think of one... 
And screw all the other reviews about this company.. it is not accurate at all. Whoever that wrote good review about this company is a big liar.
cons:
-The company system seem to be what ppl are using 20years ago. 
 -The people there have some stubborn mindset, not willing to move forward with times and technology. 
-Please expect to work overtime everyday. And oh ya, aircon shut off at 6pm. 
-The office have some serious pest problem, you can see insect crawling around everyday. 
-The office is old.. really old.. the furniture look like some left over reuse furniture that you got from cash converters.
-The meeting room look like relics left behind after world war 2.. 
-No work life balance.. there is only work, no life.. 
-In short, I would summarize the experience as going back to the army.. almost similar, only that there is no uniform and you don't have to carry a rifle.

review_title: 2 Years too soon? Living up to it's image as a career "retirement home"
pros:
Had good benefits

Has the vision to explore other opportunities and grow digitally, but they don't get the right talent or focus their resources properly.
cons:
HR and talent management are KPI driven, to them it's rarely about the people, just how they can meet their targets.

You better come in at the appropriate job position, because when you realise how strict their HR policies are, promotion and advancement will be restricted despite being an asset to the company

pros:
Great thought leadership
Company blessed with significant pool of talented employees who care for the organization 
One or two departments ran by good leaders who are able to rally their employees to drive performance for the organization
cons:
Significant rivalry across and even within each group / units led to poor collaboration and info gap between upper management and the operational teams

A toxic culture breeding in the organization where the lower management focuses on brown nosing the upper management than doing actual work that would help the company digitize/improve performance. Unfortunately, these bad leaders overwork and unfairly treat the sparingly few remaining dedicated employees, thereby driving them to leave the organization.

review_title: Very Slow career Growth but nice MNC to work
pros:
Work life balance 
Great colleagues to work with .
Continuous learning
cons:
Very very slow career growth even though the staff is keep upgrading himself & learning new things to improve .
Reward system is by seniority ,not by the level of hard work ...!!

pros: Working level people are genuine good staff
cons:
1. Bad leadership with no clear direction.
2. Lack of guidance and expect everyone to be a superman in their job. 
3. Lack of 360 Feedback system hence no proper and fair evaluation. 
4. Lack of HR support to new staff or guidance on resource info. hR too busy serving management. The coordianation for staff being let go is horrendous. No proper support and help being rendered. 
5. Lead taking credit work done well by staff.
6. No sharing of proper information.  Upper level keeping information to self.
7. HR should go beyond their  duties and help
Staff who are being let go to be deployed to another team .

Note- comments are related to my dept. i still believe there are good leaders around. Too bad i did not get to work with or meet them .

pros:
Good manager - I am lucky to have a good manager whom is caring and attentive towards subordinates.
Location - Worked in Comcentre which is located at Somerset and accessible from anywhere.
Friendly working colleagues - from my team as well as stakeholders
cons:
Slow career growth - i have a number of teammates whom have been in the organisation for more than 10 years and yet same job grade.
No career prospects - for internal transfer to another department, it will usually be a lateral transfer (no increase of job grade hence pay grade)
Out of office working hours - as i am in the Operations team, there are expectations to respond when queries/issues arises during PH or weekends.
Salary - not the best as AWS has been removed and non competitive bonus per annual (to be given during June).

pros:
Being the best telecom service provider in Asia-Pac SingTel always will be the first few to introduce technologies to the region. This will give you good satisfaction if you are a geek.
It's a regional power house and the exposure you'll get from liaising with regional partners and vendors is quite good.
With it's history of 125+ years it's a lot of nostalgic moments to share with the new people on board. ;)
cons:
Bureaucracy at best, Imagine working for a Mobile Operator yet it takes months for a inhouse mobile purchase as it's to go through 4 approvals.

Incompetent middle management

Career progression. Still somehow the promotions comes with no.of years worker as well as how old you are instead of performance and competency.

pros: Great place if you're an average achiever who just wants a job that pays the bills. Work life balance and you get to knock off on time. Lots of internal product training. If you dont know something, there's always someone that you can find to collaborate with.
cons:
Too much red tape if they count themselves as an IT firm. Still very much a telco centric company. Lots of middle and senior management who have been with the company for more than 20 years with no other transferable skills in the job market. 
A very big bell curve and they get new hire to fill the lousier grades during the annual review exercise.
Not at the frontier of the technology.

review_title: Good Place to Retire in and first jobs
pros: Nice Colleagues within the team. Big organisation enables movement between the different units.   Generous bonus with decent benefits. Good for retiring. Good for first job as well as you are given room to learn
cons:
Relatively stagnant growth projectile unless you are marked early on for success. progression is tough due to the limited space for promotions/progression and BELL curve used. Unable to retain good people due to this as well as a relatively low basic pay. Can be a pressure cooker in some departments
Intra teams - you see some very bossy colleagues.

review_title: Bittersweet, but more bitter towards the end.
pros:
Office Hours & Location.
Good Environment.
Benefits (Staff Welfare, discounts etc).
Good colleagues (at least some).
Stable company.
Recognition programmes.
cons:
No progression. Very stagnant. Difficult for internal transfer. 

Colleagues that are mostly calculative in helping out your workload and sometimes don't bother.
Management that is very critical when you make mistakes. Don't even see eye to eye. Take things personally when provide feedback and will not even acknowledge you even after years of service.

As Management, you shouldn't behave like a child when your staff has a different opinion or against an idea. There seems to be no room for open discussion.

review_title: Good working environment but Cut out the dinosaur mentality .
pros: Overall the working environment is ok, people are generally nice to work with. You get some recognition for great work done.
cons: While Singtel always promotes work life balance but there are management who don’t believe so. Some of us were given lower banding performance we went home on time, even though we met all our targets and worked really hard. And this is coming from a TM who has two kids. Why penalize us when we are efficient? We all have kids to pick up before 7pm due to preschool rules and family commitments. Management don’t see that we also make the effort to come in earlier.

pros: Singtel is customer focus. A lot of outsiders or customers may not see it that way but I know whenever a complaint is received by "C" level, Regulators, Medium etc, a lot of people is involved in resolving it.  Customer Satisfaction is a KPI that is tagged to CEO's scorecard and is cascaded down to everyone.
cons: iPhone launch is a nightmare every years.  Customer become irrationale and unreasonable.  They don't care if there is any stock or not but they also expect Singtel to have more stock than other Telco because Singtel has the biggest market share of consumers.

pros: Good reputation. Great location in town.
cons: An inner clique within senior management who lives in an ivory tower, being out of touch with rank and file of staff.  Strong blame culture.  However, there is a small group of senior management who bothers to truly engage with staff. Most executives face inordinately long hours at work. It's not unusual to see colleagues leaving past 10pm or later. Would be more productive if staff do not have to do, undo and redo work so often.

review_title: Beware of Digital Technology department. It's a big joke!
pros:
- If you are good with talking, you might be able to climb the corporate ladder
- If you are looking for a retirement company then Singtel is for you
- If you are incompetent with your tech stack - this company will support your incompetent skills, you can leech around your vendors and young talents.
cons:
- If you are looking for a challenging environment where you can refine your craft as an engineer - BEWARE. :)
- If you want a fast phased and exciting projects - BEWARE. :)
- If you are good with your work, expect 5-10 people jumping into your project because they have nothing to show to their KPIs.
- 90% of the managers doesn't have any clue with what they are doing

review_title: Go in with your eyes open.
pros:
It's a large company so there is plenty of opportunity for lateral movement and job rotation. The SingTel brand also looks good on resumes, so it's a good launching pad to further your career.

Their HR benefits are above market average.
cons:
Many staff have been working with SingTel before it was privatized and still have a stat board mentality.  They are resistant to change. 

Sales & Marketing comes up with complicated promotions and expects the support functions to be able to support these promotions on short notice (e.g within a week)

review_title: Slave driving company with a naive management.... never a place to stay for the weak-hearted
pros: Its only good if you join as a middle grade manager and above or you are looking forward to retirement the moment you join because the organisation does not have any habit of recession or sacking of staff
cons:
Poor career progression for entry level staff. 
Still function like a government despite it being a listed companies with plenty of associates around the world.
Too many layers of approval to clear for any project initiatives

review_title: Still traditional and not a very consumer-friendly company
pros: You'll get the chance to pick up a lot of people skills - managing bosses and peers etc. There are also really smart and good people inside that you can learn from.
cons: Somewhat long working hours doing work that sometimes seems "extra". Company doesn't seem to have a very human touch in dealing with consumers - and similarly with employees. Lots of hierarchy and layers.

review_title: Stressful and boring at times but the people make it all better.
pros: There's a generally lively and vibrant mood around since most of the employees at the call centre are very young. Seniors at the company don't mind helping the newbies out and they will really provide a lot of guidance. Job is relatively easy and mostly routine work.
cons: Very high turnover rate due to stress of handling customers. Sometimes it is hard to placate angry customers when even you don't agree with the way Singtel handle their customers.

pros: The company has a good system and structure. I was working for Group Digital Life and most of employees were satisfied with working ambience and culture.
cons: The company can't help being hierarchal like the other government companies. And employees who working for this company more than 15 years were normally placed as head of division and most of them had a lack of leadership, preferred to not challenge.

review_title: Overall its a good place to work
pros:
1. Big company, a lot of opportunity to learn or grow (if you are at the right department).
2. Reasonable activities arranged outside of work (team bonding, CSR activities etc).
3. Good benefit / perks for the employee.
4. Development of employee taken care quite well (courses to upgrade skill available).
5. Good bonus.
cons:
1. Opportunity of the career growth can be slow if you are not at the right department.
2. Heavy politic on certain group.
3. Small monthly salary compared to other companies.

pros: i was  think  to interview  singtel company  cos  i can learn  more about customer service . and then also can learn more different things  process in singtel. thanks
cons:
so far  was good    just only is mine downsides is  dont so like to  working at  to late  at untill same as some of company have a 24  hours shift untill 2-4am  some like that  
thanks

review_title: Applicants, since you are on this site and are considering working here, I hope this help
pros: The office is in close proximity to the train station
cons: Managers do not trust the people they are working with, teams do not trust each other, and employees engage in petty politics to one up each other. Respect for seniors (both in age and in hierarchy) is mandated, and you will be reprimanded if you object to something. Vice Presidents have no qualms yelling in your face during meetings if you question his methods. I have been in the business for 11 years, and the best advice for fresh graduates and interested applicants, would be to get out while you can (and stay out)

review_title: Good learning experience, but not sustainable as a long term job.
pros:
It's a stable company to work for, even during recessions.
Bonus is still considered competitive, but this depends on the department. 
For a department with more exposure to upper management, the average bonus is approx 2 to 3 months (excluding AWS).
For operational departments, the bonus can be as low as 1 month (excluding AWS).
cons:
The organisation is huge, and messy. This is largely due to different systems being used in different processes in the value chain.
Lots of efficiencies exist and it is difficult to change existing processes because too many parties are involved.

pros: One of the pros to work in singtel as a part-timer is that you will get to meet many young and friendly colleagues like yourself. Also, the pay is slightly higher than other company at $8/hr and OTs are additionally paid. Work load is manageable and it depends on the department you are in.
cons: if you are taking the job full time, there might be chances that you will stay in the department and position for quite long. Career progression is slow and changing from being a contract staff to permanent staff would take a long while.

review_title: Fast paced with opportunities for experimenting with new ideas
pros:
Organisation has the willpower and discipline to innovate and test out new ideas
Much more than a telco with opportunities across all emerging tech fields
Good team mates that make it possible to launch and run new initiatives.
cons: Ironically for an organisation that spends a lot of time and effort for their annual operating plan, day-to-day exigencies seem to stem from lack of planning or last minute requests from some leaders that could be managed in a more thoughtful manner.

review_title: I work with some great people, who are passionate about what they do
pros: You're providing an essential service to Singapore which is rewarding. Being a large organisation there are many opportunities to try different roles and there are lots of passionate people to work with. There is a genuine desire to give customers a great experience.
cons: There are few silos, people tend to focus only on their own role and not on the bigger picture. Systems sometimes hinder the ability to offer great customer service.

pros: Good place to coast and retire in without having to break a sweat. Can come in around 9am instead of 8.30am cos the bosses come in even later than you, Central & convenient location; can go for > 2 hour lunch break & run personal errands during office hours without being missed cos almost everyone on the same floor does it.
cons: None, if you just want to pass your time with minimum effort. Some people are just passing time there, can't get a job elsewhere,  or waiting to strike Toto. Work-wise, the people here can get away with it just as long as they do the minimum.

pros: Nice location and stable/simple job
cons:
1) Commoditized business: Telco businesses are all protected from commoditization thanks to government protection and not "know-how" or "IP". This will lead to significant lay-off and continue low pay
2) No turnaround strategy: the company has no realistic strategy to avoid the commoditization of its core business. This is due to its small footprint (Singapore) and its lack of leadership experience in all new industries (none of the leaders have worked in the industry in which Singtel has trier to diversify which has led to poor acquisition). This leads to top talent drainage and distrust in leadership.
3) Old mom&pap culture: below average pay, control-freak management committee, 3 force ranking, 6 month budget planning, old infrastructure

review_title: Singtel - Private sector with government style management
pros:
Good exposure in my role
Independent with flexibility to fix my own schedules
Free mobile phone services and slight discounts on company services
in-house recreation club and facilities
cons:
Bureaucratic structure
Long hours and frequent overloading of the competent staff
Unfair retention and promotion of non-performing staff
Very poor career development prospects if you started in a junior position

pros: Entry level job. They provide sufficient training if you are a newbie and ensure that you are well equipped before turning live on the job. You get to improve a lot on your soft skills as you need to speak to  customers daily.  You will also learn to be professional when managing difficult clients and your bosses. Singtel also always give mini treats monthly to encourage you in your work, quarterly talk by your senior management on the companies' achievement and objectives, celebrate festive seasons with good food and performance, and many other non-monetary benefits.
cons:
Lack of progression - You'll probably be stuck as a call centre agent unless your team leader/manager resigns or internally transferred.

Lack of autonomy - You are not given enough empowerment to do your job ,
(especially for team leaders).

High turnover - You get to meet new colleagues every few months, not an issue for call agent. If you are a team leader/manager, it could be tough guiding newbies every few months and still have to meet KPI.

Employee retention programme - None. Someone (from management) told me that all employees are dispensable. Hence, that should explain the high turnover.

Lack of engagement from line managers - The only time you seat down to have a proper engagement will be due to lateness, coaching or to sign a warning letter. In my opinion, coaching should be in a form of development through advice and guidance. However, the call centre has "mistakenly" took coaching as a form of "warning" already.

P.S. To all potential candidates out there, don't be discourage and I assure you that call centre is actually a good learning ground for a fresh grad; or if you are currently pursuing part time education.

pros:
the "people skills" which you will learn
the mobile technologies
if you like to climb the corporate ladder
most of the operational support employees give their best and are loyal to the company. some environments are very warm and supportive.
cons: hierarchical, political, promotion may not be based on performance,  incompetent middle management, business functions are not close enough to the customers (not listening hard enough), lack of empowerment for ground/operational staff, unwillingness of some middle management to take responsibilities for their own decisions/actions

review_title: Stable and competitive company with good management
pros:
Lots of learning opportunities. Competitive spirit means that company performs consistently which translates to consistent AWS and bonus payout and no cost cutting measures that affect employee welfare. 
Higher management works really hard.
cons:
Management squeeze the most from you - also depends on department. If you can cope then the experience gained will boost your market value as an employee. 
Climbing the corporate ladder here means you job scope and what is expected from you rise exponentially.

pros: Great culture and high empowerment by superior. In SingTel, ideas are allowed to flow freely and bosses listen to what you have before approval is given to proceed with the idea. As SingTel constantly brings in fresh and new products, sometimes ahead of competitors, we must adapt methods that is out of the box but at the same time, approaches must be acceptable by companies which are never much localized.
cons: We are faced with constant changes year on year hence, we customize our reach to the mass. This changes takes a while to be understand before we can ride on it and accelerate.

pros:
- will try to retain you even if you're  ill or not that good 
- Does a lot of work in motivating employees (constantly give us gifts)
- Good rewards, incentives and bonuses
cons:
- Will fail KPI if you take MC, affecting your incentives.
- a lot of employees have habit of pushing their work to others
- Talking to other department's managers can be a headache. Will even refuse to talk to you just because you're not of the same level. Even if they do, they can be so nasty.

review_title: Great place to learn with some of the most hardworking people I've seen.
pros:
Established policies and practices; many industry best practices to learn from.
Most managers are progressive thinkers and are open to discuss flexible working arrangements.
Teams are bonded on the working level, and generally willing to help one another. 
Comfortable amount of staff benefits, recreational facilities/ amenities made available.
Challenging work environment, and opportunities to embark on business improvement projects.
cons:
Cumbersome processes and rounds of approvals required, which hinders getting tasks done.
Large organization, and hence you often get re-directed to many different persons before arriving at the right in-charge to handle your requests.

review_title: Honest review from a rank and file employee.
job_title: Customer Care Officer II in Singapore
pros:
Colleagues treat each other like family. 
If you are a local / pr with families here, the benefits on top of basic salary are really over the top. 
Brand name gives big value on resume.
cons:
Not much room for career advancement. 
Management not able to retain/develop further skills of its well performing staff. 
Basic Salary is not very competitive. 
Business oriented rather than employee oriented
Not much training provided or too much focus on service level concerns.

pros: Good work life balance. Alot of free time. Everyone can spend 1 -  2 hours for tea break + a normal 2 hour lunch. Knocks off at 6pm
cons: Rots the brain. No stimulation. It gets to you if you have some common sense. I suggest leaving them behind when you go to work.

review_title: One of the Most Toxic Places to Work In!
pros: Near the MRT.  Near Orchard Road - you will need the retail therapy after a day's work at this toxic environment
cons: Insecure turf guarding bosses at mid-management (and probably at top too, but I can't be sure).  A lot of wayang puppet actors in front of bosses especially during off-site retreats.  A long drawn budgeting process every year with sales people under declaring their targets and having to be probed constantly why they cannot deliver more challenging targets.  There are also directors and VPs using foul language with staff - basically a lack of respect within that culture. Am just glad to be out.

pros:
Awesome colleagues 
Benefits not too shabby
cons:
- HR was cold towards their own people leaving. No one even bothered to do an exit interview. I had to manage my own. 
- Performance rating system may not be the best (bell curve system)
- High turnover rate within HR
- Only start to look into problems when they happen. Some issues could have been avoided. 
- Listen to your employees. Encourage feedback and not give passive aggressive remarks.

review_title: Not a nice place to work in.  Should seriously consider your other options before taking up the offer here.
pros:
Work location is in Orchard Road. So its accessible by MRT and also buses. 
It's easy to get a Manager's position here - just with a few years of work experience.
cons:
Extremely long work hours.
Bureaucracy as the place is still managed like the good old days of Singapore Telecoms.
Vicious Politics with Management supporting an ultra competitive and cut-throat environment.
Lots of Foreign Talent - some working as peers to you but with qualifications and background which does not commensurate to  the local standards of education and employment experience.

pros: Good and stable job. Work-life balance is good. Many old colleagues choose to stay in this company. Will work for singtel again if given a chance.
cons: Low starting salary. Big company means there is politics. pay increase is on the lower side due to the bell curve. and opportunities to move up could take very long. could take ages.

review_title: Organisation moving too slow with too much meaningless work
pros:
- Decent benefits
- Good rotational opportunities
cons:
- Long hours due to lots of work that has no meaningful impact to the company
- Too many processes that makes things run very slowly
- Spend too much time on planning rather than proper execution

pros: Working environment is good ! Met a group of nice colleagues & managers . There will be outlet outing , company outing too .  You will learn alot and experiences too .
cons: Hard to have work life balance as you may need to work till midnight sometimes. Lunch time will be cut short to 30mins during peak periods . Aggressive & unreasonable customers .

pros: Good pay, very supportive colleagues and fun environment to work in. A lot of opportunities given to management associates.
cons: Too big with old processes and policies that slow down a lot of projects. Getting approval from line manager takes >1 week which is honestly too long despite repeated reminder

pros: Friendly environment, good learning platform, stable work environment (minimal retrenchment)
cons: Limited growth opportunities, hierarchical - leading to slower decisions, work hard but not necessarily work smart mentality

review_title: Be prepared to sell your life
pros:
Competitive salary package
Friendly colleagues
Central office location
cons:
Be prepared to be on standby all the time, throwing your work life balance out of the window
Too many red tapes, really feels like working for the government
Stressful culture
Lots of politics at the higher levels

pros: Great colleague, very good place to learn about telco business. HQ is here in Singapore, so support is never an issue.
cons: Support is never an issue if you could escalate high enough. Politics prevents most task from being easy.

review_title: Can Telco people win in the Internet era?
pros: The need to change is taken seriously. The challenger spirit is alive. The job security is real.
cons: Telco-mentality still present, partners are treated like vendors, arrogant attitude towards internet space

pros: Family oriented culture, great benefits, opportunities to explore various career path, stable industry
cons: Due to the nature of the industry the Company is in, re-organisation is often required. However, the management seem to over-look that certain process and system are legacy and might not be readily changed, resulting in additional work for the back-end support.

review_title: Singtel is changing for the better, but very slowly
pros:
- Once you understand how the organisation works, it gets easier
- While it is more complex than it needs to be, managers generally understand the difference between system issues and people issues.
cons:
- Lots of complexity, even in the most basic functions. 
- Very mono-cultural. Close to zero non-Chinese.

pros:
Great job security. 
Good training ground for fresh graduates.
Some business units are silo in operations, with their own resources and things get done efficiently.
cons:
Too many layers with too many processes and too many applications.
Internal cross functional teams are not aligned, those business units without their own resources will struggle in daily operations.

review_title: Gained good exposure working as an Engineering Officer in an Technical Helpdesk.
pros: Working in a large enterprise and specializing with cutting edge technologies
cons: Reason for my quit, office was relocated to the other end of Singapore.

review_title: Best company I have ever worked
pros:
1. No pressure
2. Good team mates
3. Nice boss (especially my managers)
4. Work life harmony
cons:
1. As a programmer, sometimes you may have some difficulties to learn their sw dev env.
2. Will not guide / brief about their system and have to start by urself.
3. Sometimes deadline are weird.

pros:
Acceptable work-life balance.
Intangible benefits (but low salary).
Good place to show your talent if you allow yourself to be made use by the middle management without expecting any returns.
cons:
Certain long serving staffs in Middle management control the growth of the competent executives.
Broadcasting of negative feedback to higher management to cover their incompetency.
Make false promises and unscrupulousness working ethics by middle and top management.

review_title: Revenue driven and has a structured process. Good and bad in its way.
pros: Killiney office has all the amenities like groceries and gym and even shopping needs. cheap food too where's canteen at basement.
cons: Not pertaining to the company but is your leader and boss that makes the environment unfriendly and unproductive at work.

review_title: Many Training And Learning Opportunities, Not so Competitive Pay
pros: Opportunities for training is abundant, SingTel advocates learning and upgrading skills. Depending on who your supervisor is, some can be quite forgiving.
cons: Too revenue driven. Pay not competitive.

pros: Big organisation, gradual learning curve with opportunities in the various dept.
cons: there is still some resistance to change in the middle management group

pros: Have good medical benefits. Opportunity to participate in major events like F1, etcs.
cons: Promotion is not based on merits but on whether your Boss's Boss like you or not.  Salary on low side not align with market.

review_title: Staff benefits not bad but pay low
pros: Staff canteen n good location. Staff benefits not bad. There's a gym and staff lounge which you can access during lunch break.
cons: Not systematic and not structured. People don't like to send and received email.

review_title: Top management requirement is not clear
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Jurong West New Town,
pros: Good company benefits and good pay also
cons: Work life can’t balance, staff don’t understand the top management, work without a clear goal.

pros:
nice, good colleagues
location near to MRT station

those who can work will be get more tasks, projects. in the end it's our fault if we can't deliver.
politics within departement

pros: Established organization with huge growth potential; made many changes to meet changing market landscape.  Many supporting departments each with clear distinction on functions.

pros:

Lots of learning opportunities

Fairly top down approach

pros: Good pay, also very singaporean environment. Experienced employees. The company will need to reduce its crazy work hours. Great training ground.
cons: Messy company operations, unclear direction from the management. The company will need to reduce its crazy work hours. And also not try to cover up mistakes

pros: You receive discounts on Singtel products.  The location is great for lunch and shopping around Orchard.   There is also a large food court in ComCentre.
cons: If you are looking for a role to sit back, do little and retire, then Singtel is the place for you.  There is a level of bureaucracy that prevents innovation and creativity.  Go there at the start or end of your career.

pros:
Flexible Working Hours
Work life balance
Nice co-worker
cons:
Extremely Bureaucratic
Poor Management
Poor staff retention
Low Pay
Minimum rewards even if you exceed KPI.

pros: Good diversity in business. Able to learn different skills.
cons: Some employees have been here for too long e.g more than 10 years and lack the latest knowledge in technology. Depending on team, some older folks do create a toxic environment.

review_title: great training ground for fresh grads
pros: resource rich, stable player in tech field, incumbent operator in SG, good health benefits
cons: defensive culture, negative politics, hierarchical, generally low basic salaries, work life balance commonly close to non-existent, HR is pro-management

review_title: Good place to learn about enterprise technology.
pros: Good work life balance, will get to see big infrastructure upgrades, handle clusters of servers.
cons: Like all big companies, there are bureaucracies and processes, double edged sword.

review_title: Not a good place for internship
pros: Big company with almost local people. You can learn stuff from your group.

professional culture

working environment

working places

review_title: Great learning/traning ground for those who are willing to sacrifice work life balance

review_title: As wide and diverse a career as you are prepared to back yourself on
pros:
I have been with Singtel for 30 years since graduating, and have had one of the widest and most diversified career across many different roles, different functional skills and working across the region in Singapore, Philippines and Australia. Some have been mainstream roles, some start-up, many in different areas outside my core training, and some I had a chance to shape and create when the role didn't first exist. 

My insights on the company is Singtel management is very supportive of your learning and growth, of moving into new roles. It comes down to your willingness to constantly learn new things, challenge yourself and back yourself. If so, the management and culture supports that very well. It is also a purposeful organization that also respects the individual diversity. So I have always had the opportunity to weave in a broader purpose and my own purpose into my roles, such as to positively impact society, our customers, the environment which is very important as many other companies are there just to make money. 

Part of my success is that I have also failed in some roles when I took a risk and really stretched myself into new and challenging areas. You only fail if you are not willing to pick yourself up and give it another go, and the culture supports you giving it a go.
cons: If you like an industry that is fast paced, ever-changing with room for constant innovation, this is also the industry and company to be in. But if you want things to be predictable, unexciting and low risk, then it may be better to consider elsewhere.

pros:
I often read Glassdoor, and stumbled across one of my previous contracts that I left in 2021.

It's a fast paced business for sure, who are trying to do something different in moving to a marketplace. It isn't for everybody, and in my experience of being at SS it is clear there are a lot of "hangers on" - people that log on at 9am and log off at 5pm.

Nothing wrong with that, but it's much more fast paced than that, and you can see that since the company was purchased, a lot has been done to actually run it like a company (I believe the previous owners had it in millions of £££ of debt).

A lot of the "former" staff on here obviously have a gripe - which you can understand, Glassdoor is a great place to vent if you want to be seen as bitter, but you can do it anonymously. 

Honestly though, in my experience it was a good place to work, and they have some really talented people now.

Perhaps a bit different as a contractor, but they treated me well.
cons: A lot of people don't understand what the company is trying to do clearly - I think that is an issue from the CEO (strategy), but also because a lot of people just don't understand the industry.

- No more work-life balance - it used to be really good.

- Politics is rampant.

review_title: Absentee Managers, Penny Pinching and lack of direction
pros: The job itself was rewarding. Colleagues across the globe. Life/work balance.  Good company to work for until a couple of years ago.
cons: Penny pinching is having a deteriorating effect across the business. Management don't look after their staff (on the last day of work our boss took the day off!).  It's easy for incompetent people to hide and someone else will do the job. Chaotic  and lengthy bureaucracy.  Very little training offered and virtually no personal development for staff outside of Singapore. In fact, all benefits are Singapore-centric and career progress is mostly for those in Singapore.  On paper they have excellent values but in practice only a small portion is applied.

Contrary to popular belief, NO, you do not get free mobile lines unless your work requires you to have one. Nothing is free, subsidized corporate rates are not of a better deal than those they give to customers. If you are here for cheaper mobile rate, you came to the wrong place. Go join a bank or something.

Too much segregation between junior and senior officers. HR policies are not aligned in the organization, some departments get better benefits than others although people are doing similar jobs and have similar background. HR need a huge revamp, not just their office. 

Not a good starting place for a fresh grad. Go somewhere else. This place has an average age of 40. Lots of red tapes and slow moving processes that frustrate people.
